title: 113_hr5120
content:
The Department of Energy Laboratory Modernization and Technology Transfer Act of 2014 includes sections on short title, definitions, savings clause, innovation management, under secretary for science and energy, technology transfer assessment, sense of Congress, cross-sector partnerships, and grant competitiveness. The Department of Energy Laboratory Modernization and Technology Transfer Act of 2014 includes sections on agreements for commercializing technology, public-private partnerships, early-stage technology demonstration, funding competitiveness for institutions of higher education, participation in the Innovation Corps program, and assessment of impact through a report by the Government Accountability Office. The Department of Energy Laboratory Modernization and Technology Transfer Act of 2014 defines the Department as the Department of Energy and National Laboratories as nonmilitary national laboratories under the Department, including specific named labs. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy. The Department of Energy Laboratory Modernization and Technology Transfer Act of 2014 defines the Department as the Department of Energy and National Laboratories as nonmilitary national laboratories under the Department, including specific named labs such as Savannah River National Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, and any laboratory operated by the National Nuclear Security Administration for civilian energy activities. SEC. 3. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not affect the primary responsibilities of any National Laboratory to the Department. TITLE I--INNOVATION MANAGEMENT AT DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY SEC. 101. UNDER SECRETARY FOR SCIENCE AND ENERGY. The Department of Energy Organization Act is amended to change the title of the Under Secretary for Science to the Under Secretary for Science and Energy. The Under Secretary is tasked with establishing linkages between offices and performing duties as prescribed by the Secretary. Conforming amendments are also made. The Department of Energy Organization Act amends titles to include "Science and Energy" for the Under Secretary. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of related acts. SEC. 102. TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER ASSESSMENT.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary must submit a report to the House and Senate committees assessing the Department's ability to achieve the goals of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. This includes evaluating the Technology Transfer Coordinator's role and effectiveness, along with proposing policy and legislative changes to enhance technology transfer to the private sector.

SEC. 103. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The Congress acknowledges the importance of the independent Commission to Review the Effectiveness of the National Energy Laboratories in developing a strategy for the National Laboratories. Congress anticipates receiving the Commission's findings and aims to work with the Administration to enhance the mission and modernize the operations of the National Laboratories. The Secretary is urged to support the National Laboratories. The Secretary should encourage National Laboratories and research centers to inform small businesses of opportunities and resources under this Act. Title II introduces the Agreement for Commercializing Technology Pilot Program under SEC. 201. The Secretary will implement the Agreements for Commercializing Technology pilot program for National Laboratories, allowing increased authority for contractors to negotiate terms like intellectual property rights and payment structures. Eligibility extends to any National Laboratory director for entering into agreements with non-federal entities. The Secretary will allow National Laboratory directors to enter agreements with non-Federal entities, with funding used solely for Federal award purposes. The Bayh-Dole Act applies if the agreement is a funding agreement and one party is eligible for rights under that chapter. The affected National Laboratory directors must submit project details, costs, and timelines to the Secretary for each agreement. The contractor must certify that the project activities do not compete with the private sector and minimize conflicts. The pilot program must not have conflicts of interest and should be extended for 2 years. The Secretary will submit a report assessing the program's effectiveness and suggesting improvements to the relevant committees. The Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress on the pilot program, including recommendations for improvement and transparency regarding non-Federal entities using funds from Federal contracts. SEC. 202. PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR COMMERCIALIZATION. The Secretary can delegate signature authority to National Laboratory directors for agreements under $1,000,000. This includes cooperative research agreements, non-Federal work agreements, and other appropriate agreements. Directors must adhere to Department policies when carrying out these agreements. The director of a National Laboratory must ensure that agreements do not compromise national security, economic, or environmental interests. Certification and record submission are required for activities under agreements. Rates for National Laboratory projects may be determined by the director. The director of a National Laboratory can charge higher rates for services under a partnership agreement to support further research activities. Amendment to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act allows for adjustments in rates by Federal agencies. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act allows National Laboratories to charge higher rates for services under partnership agreements for research. An exception to approval by the Secretary of Energy is made for technology transfer agreements costing less than $1,000,000. SEC. 203 amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to allow National Laboratories to conduct early-stage technology demonstration activities using funds for technology transfer. SEC. 204 focuses on funding competitiveness for higher education and nonprofit institutions. Section 988(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 is amended to include an exemption for research or development activities performed by institutions of higher education or nonprofit institutions. This exemption applies for a 6-year period. During the 6-year period after enactment, subparagraph (A) applies. The Secretary may partner with the National Science Foundation for researchers funded by the Department to join the Innovation Corps program. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within 3 years of this Act's enactment, detailing the outcomes of projects under sections 201, 202, and 203. This includes information on partnerships formed, potential linkages to national priorities, fiscal savings, National Laboratory capabilities, technology transfer efficiency, and general efficiency improvements. The Comptroller General of the United States will report to Congress on the outcomes of projects under sections 201, 202, and 203, including partnerships, fiscal savings, National Laboratory capabilities, and technology transfer efficiency. Additionally, an assessment will be made on the Department's efforts to enhance technology transfer and private sector engagement at the National Laboratories, with recommendations for improvement. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 22, 2014. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
